pros: Very few. Heath plan was decent but all benefits were slowly but surely being cut. Dominican ideals were occasionally practiced.
cons: One of the worst teaching and work environments I’ve ever experienced. A highly passive aggressive work environment where there was a great deal of infighting within departments and across departments. President and administration would often tout an atmosphere of “transparency” however then made major restructuring strategic plans that laid off a large amount of tenured faculty with only a few weeks notice before Christmas. Pay for faculty was abysmally low, with benefits shrinking—sabbaticals, for example, were simply suspended without notice. Teaching load was high with additional “non-mandatory” work expected on a regular basis. There was a constant sense of secrecy from upper administration which led to a shady work environment. Job security was in doubt for many years leading to a sense of paranoia, confusion, and rumors among faculty and staff. High performing and professionally successful professors were undervalued and professional development was not rewarded. This regularly led to the most successful professors and scholars quitting. In some cases this included harassment/academic sabotage of faculty to create a hostile work environment that helped to push them out. Most recently this also led to a mass lay-off of dedicated longterm professors and staff who had given 10-20+ years of commitment and service to the university. Heartless decision making from senior administration. Faculty was not listened to or generally valued by administration or leadership, leading to greater faculty dissatisfaction. A recent increase in replacing longtime faculty with adjuncts in order to cut costs. Diversity and Inclusion was abysmal, with major problems occurring on the administration level (leading to faculty voicing votes of no confidence) and complete dismissal of faculty concerns. This is not a place you want to work.

job_title: Graduate Assistant- Athletic Department in Adrian, MI
pros: I worked in the athletic department as a GA. The biggest pro was free tuition. The graduate programs are offered in a blended online and in person format which was convenient.
cons: No training or support from the athletic department was provided. It was up to the individual coach how to use their GA. Most GA's complained of not feeling like they were given any responsibility or that there time was not used well. Overall, the athletic department and entire University seemed to value brown nosers over hard workers. It was very much a good old boys feel day in and day out. Also, if you want to pursue a career in athletics a GA spot within the NCAA membership of schools would be best. NAIA is a joke.
